Captain Noel Godfrey Chavasse participated in the Balkan Wars and the Palestine Campaign during World War I, before serving in the British Army on the Western Front, where he was awarded his two Victoria Crosses.

During the Balkan Wars, which took place between 1912 and 1913, Chavasse served as part of a British medical mission in Serbia. He worked tirelessly to care for wounded soldiers on both sides of the conflict, and was known for his bravery and selflessness under fire.

In the Palestine Campaign, which began in late 1916 and lasted until the end of World War I, Chavasse served as a medical officer in the British Army. He was responsible for treating wounded soldiers in a variety of difficult conditions, including during the Battle of Gaza in 1917, where he worked tirelessly to treat injured soldiers despite heavy enemy fire.

Chavasse's experiences during these campaigns undoubtedly prepared him for the challenges he would face on the Western Front, where he became known as one of the most heroic and dedicated medical officers of the First World War.
